text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
IRM 4.75.24 contains guidance for examining central and subordinate organizations covered under a group return.
MATERIAL CHANGES
Converted the manual to plain language. For more guidance on plain language, see www. plainlanguage.gov.
Eliminated all references to “intermediate organizations” throughout the manual.
IRM 4.75.24.3(7): Deleted language that we are allowed to contact the Central Organization while auditing the subsidiary.

IRM 4.75.24.4(3): Revocation of the Central Organization terminates the group ruling and removed language stating that the Central Organization revocation is not subject to IRC 7428 as that does not follow the PATH Act.
Changed the Exempt Organizations structure in accordance with the reorganization. (ie; references to EO Manager, Examination Programs and Review (EPR) becomes Area Manager, GL/FIU.
Removed old Exhibit
“Notiﬁcation Letter to Central Organization - Revocation of Subordinate,” and replaced it with published Letter
Removed old Exhibit
“Notiﬁcation Letter to Central Organization - Termination of Subordinate,” replaced it with published Letter
Removed old Exhibit
“Central Organization
Day Proposed Revocation Letter (
)),” replaced it with published letter
Removed old Exhibit
“Secure E-Mail Message...Termination of a Central terminations no longer go through Mandatory Review Staff. Letter
is replaced with Letter
old Exhibit 4.75.24-4 “Central Organization 30 Day Proposed Revocation Letter replaced it with published letter 3618.
Removed old Exhibit 4.75.24-6 “Secure E-Mail Message...Termination of a Central Organization,” as terminations no longer go through Mandatory Review Staff.
Letter 5326 is replaced with Letter 5918.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

This revision supersedes IRM 4.75.24, Organizations Covered by a Group Ruling, dated July 3, 2017. This revision incorporates: Interim Guidance Memorandum TEGE-04-0216-0003, PATH ACT-Impact on Revocations and Modiﬁcations Exempt Status. Interim Guidance Memorandum TEGE-04-0419-0010, Reissuance: Procedures Following the Reorganization.

Covered by a Group Ruling 4.75.24
Purpose: This manual focuses on an examiner’s responsibilities for examina- tions of organizations under a group ruling. It addresses these topics:
Consult the Knowledge Management Network (K-Net) to ensure you’ve properly developed issues and consistently applied the law.
The table lists commonly used acronyms and their deﬁnitions.
Exempt Organizations Examination Procedures
REV. PROC. Revenue Procedure (

) A “central” or “parent” organization is an organization recognized as exempt that has one or more subordinates under its general supervision or control. The central organization that holds a group exemption (not the IRS) deter- mines which organizations are included as subordinates under its group exemption ruling. (
) A “subordinate” may consist of a: • Chapter • Local • Post, or • Unit of a central organization. (
) A subordinate may or may not be incorporated, but it must have an document. (

) Central organizations must establish that each of the subordinates included the group ruling meet all these criteria: a. Affiliated with the parent at the close of its annual accounting period. b. Subjected to the parent’s general supervision or control. c. Exempt under the same paragraph of IRC

(c) as the other subordi- nates. d. Not organized or operated as a private foundation. e. Not organized and operated in a foreign country. Note: The central organization doesn’t have to be exempt under the same paragraph of IRC
(c) as its subordinates. The subordinates must be exempt under the same paragraph of IRC
) See IRM
, Group Exemption Requirements, for a discussion of requirements for exemption of the subordinates. (
) Group rulings present unique situations: a. Central organization can add and remove subordinate organizations a group ruling, simply by updating their annual list of subordinates.
Central organizations must establish that each of the subordinates included in the group ruling meet all these criteria:
Affiliated with the parent at the close of its annual accounting period. Subjected to the parent’s general supervision or control. Exempt under the same paragraph of IRC
(c) as the other subordi- nates. Not organized or operated as a private foundation. Not organized and operated in a foreign country.
Central organization can add and remove subordinate organizations from a group ruling, simply by updating their annual list of subordinates.
Covered by a Group Ruling 4.75.24
The IRS can terminate the exemption for a subordinate organization or the central organization, or can terminate the group ruling in its entirety.

) You can’t modify a subordinate organization’s exempt status without modifying the group ruling itself. To terminate the exempt status of a subordinate is to remove it from the group ruling. If a subordinate fails to qualify for tax-exempt status under the same paragraph of IRC
(c) as the other subordinates in the group, you must remove it from the group ruling, even if it may qualify for another paragraph in IRC
Example: ABC, a veterans’ organization, is a subordinate organization covered by a group exemption ruling held by its parent organization. All subordinates in the group are exempt under IRC
). ABC’s Form
for
is under examination. The examiner determines that ABC doesn’t meet the requirements of IRC
) because it fails the membership tests. ABC does, however qualify for tax-exemption under IRC
). Accordingly, you must propose revocation under IRC
), remove it from the group ruling, and encourage it to apply for
a group exemption ruling held by its parent organization. All in the group are exempt under IRC
). ABC’s Form
for
is under examination. The examiner determines that ABC doesn’t meet the requirements of IRC
) because it fails the membership tests. ABC does, however qualify for tax-exemption IRC
). Accordingly, you must propose revocation under IRC
), remove it from the group ruling, and encourage it to tax-exempt status under IRC
). Subordinates who obtain a separate determination letter are no longer under the group ruling. The subordinates will lose their individual letter if they join a group ruling. See IRM
). Administratively, group rulings result in fewer applications for exemption. ordinates of a group ruling can also opt to reduce the number of returns by ﬁling a group return. See IRM
Group rulings also complicate the issue of the statute of limitations. See

: a. Which return(s) start the running of the statute of limitations? b. Who is authorized to sign an extension? c. Who signs when the organization under examination ﬁled via a return? Group rulings also modify the notiﬁcation procedures. IRS must, in certain ations, contact the central organization. A central organization may ﬁle, under
CFR

(d), in addition to own annual information return, a group return on behalf of two or more of subordinate organizations covered by a group ruling: a. Affiliated with the central organization at the close of its annual ing period. b. Subjected to the general supervision or control of the central tion. c. Exempt under the same paragraph of IRC

(c) as the other nates. d. Filed based on the established annual accounting period of the organization. The group return may include only those exempt subordinates that have rized in writing, the central organization to include them in the return The subordinates must submit to the central organization statements
Affiliated with the central organization at the close of its annual ing period. Subjected to the general supervision or control of the central organiza- tion. Exempt under the same paragraph of IRC
(c) as the other subordi- nates. Filed based on the established annual accounting period of the central organization.
4.75 Exempt Organizations Examination Procedures
their gross income, receipts and disbursements, as well as such other informa- tion relating to them as is required to be stated in the group return.
Any subordinates not included in a group return are subject to the standard ﬁling requirements and must ﬁle one of the following forms, as appropriate:
The central organization may not include itself on the group return. The central organization must ﬁle its own separate return. See 26 CFR 1-6033-2(d).
The central organization is subject to the standard ﬁling requirements:
Covered by a Group Ruling 4.75.24
Organizations eligible to submit the e-Postcard or ﬁle Form 990-EZ may choose to ﬁle a full return.

A central organization ﬁling a group return on behalf of two or more affiliates uses a special Employer Identiﬁcation Number (EIN) to ﬁle the group return. The organization is provided this special EIN with its group ruling letter. To research the EIN, use command code EOGEN (Exempt Organization Group Exemption Number) using the group exemption number (GEN) to ﬁnd the EIN of the group return. Consult the Field Agent Support Team (FAST) if you can’t ﬁnd the EIN through regular IDRS research.
Note: EOGEN will tell you the parent and all the subs. You must look through all the subs until you ﬁnd the one they are using to ﬁle the group return.

) A subordinate organization may or may not be included on a group return. Review BMFOLT (Business Master File Online Transcript) on IDRS for the sub- ordinate’s EIN for the year in question. If a subordinate has been included on the group return, BMFOLT reﬂects a transaction code (TC)
and closing code (CC)
The transaction will also reﬂect a “PAR EIN XX-XXXXXXX”. (
) If a subordinate claims to have been included on a group return, but IDRS doesn’t show a TC
CC
, secure a copy of the group return via Online SEIN. Review the return to see whether the subordinate is listed as included on the group return. Contact the FAST unit to request them to input TC
of the group exemption. In this situation, the subordinate’s status on BM- FOLO (Business Master File Online Organization)/INOLES (Online Entity) is
, and is subject to a Form
ﬁling requirement. (
) If included on a group return, the subordinate’s statute of limitations is based on the group return. See IRM
) to determine the statute of tions. If the subordinate is not included on the group return, it is subject to normal ﬁling requirements. See IRM
) for the ﬁling requirements. If no return is ﬁled, secure a delinquent return. See IRM
, EO Delin- quent, Amended and Substitute for Return Procedures.
Exempt Organizations Examination Procedures
If the subordinate is neither included on a group return nor ﬁles its own return for three consecutive years, the organization is subject to auto revoca

tion. If auto revoked, the subordinate may apply for reinstatement of its exempt status. Don’t secure a delinquent return in these situations. If the parent organization fails to ﬁle its own return for three consecutive years, the parent organization is automatically revoked and the entire group ruling is terminated.
See below for officers authorized to sign a consent:

If examining a Authorized to sign consent Subordinate organization’s own Officers of the subordinate. If au- Form 990 series return thorized, officers of the central organization may sign on behalf of the subordinate. Central organization Only officers of the central organi- zation. Group return Officers of the central organiza- tion. Use the special EIN of the group return Note: In some circumstances, contact Area Counsel when the subordinates are separate legal entities, such as corporations, trusts or other entities.
Covered by a Group Ruling 4.75.24
Appeals won’t accept cases with less than 180 days remaining on the statute of limitations.
) When a case is returned to EO Examinations for correction(s) the examiner must ensure there is at least
days left on the statue of limitations before sending the case back to Appeals. (
) For an unagreed case without protests, the case must have at least
days remaining on the statute of limitations when Review receives it, or it is returned to the groups for the ﬁnal letter. (
) You should not notify the central organization of your examination of a subordi- nate organization unless authorized to do so by the subordinate organization.
You should not notify the central organization of your examination of a subordi- nate organization unless authorized to do so by the subordinate organization.
Exception: modiﬁcations, terminations and revocations

If you can’t contact the subordinate organization, contact the central tion for help contacting the subordinate’s officers. The central organization is responsible for ensuring that the subordinate organization continues to meet the requirements for exemption under the group ruling.

) Prepare all letters issued to the taxpayer. For Mandatory Review letters, the contact information ﬁelds blank. Upload the letter to the Reporting ance Case Management System (RCCMS) and note on the Form
-A, TE/GE Special Handling Notice, the ﬁle name for the letter and its folder location on RCCMS. (

) When you’re determining that a subordinate organization should no longer tax-exempt, you are effectively proposing to remove the organization from group ruling. This terminates their exempt status, and constitutes an action that triggers the subordinate’s rights to appeal. When writing the of examination, minimize the use of terms like “revoke” and “revocation.” Instead, use the phrase “removal from the group exemption” or some (
) Removal of any subordinates that are under an IRC
(c) group ruling triggers the administrative record requiremen if unagreed. See IRM
, Declaratory Judgment Cases And The Administrative Record for unagreed cases (per IGM TE/GE-

) Revocation of the central organization’s exempt status results in the tion of the group ruling as a whole. The subordinate organizations may seek their own individual recognition, join another group ruling, or if a statutorily exempt organization continue as exempt without recognition. The central nization is subject to declaratory judgment procedures under IRC
and Mandatory Review (or Appeals) issues a
-day ﬁnal adverse determination letter (FADL). Contact Mandatory Review for a custom agreed revocation See also IRM
, Final Case Processing. (
) For all revocations of central or subordinate organizations under prepare Form
-A, Request for IDRS Input for BMF/EO Entity Change, update the Exempt Organizations Business Master File (EO BMF) status to
Note: The exam group issues Letter 3618 and other custom 30-day letters, and if the agent receives a valid protest, Letter 5918. Mandatory Review issues all of the other letters.

For all revocations of central or subordinate organizations under examination, prepare Form 2363-A, Request for IDRS Input for BMF/EO Entity Change, to update the Exempt Organizations Business Master File (EO BMF) status to

If a central organization is revoked, the GEN ﬁle updates all the subordinates to status

) Organizations that have their own exemption letter are corporations, trusts or associations. Organizations included under a group ruling may receive from the central organization. This is common with many fraternal and veterans’ organizations. (

) When examining a subordinate that has a charter from the central organiza- tion, in lieu of or in addition to a certiﬁcate of incorporation, determine the charter has been rescinded/revoked by the central organization. Obtain a copy of the letter rescinding/revoking the charter of the subordinate entity. (

) When a central organization dissolves/terminates, is revoked, or relinquishes its exemption, then recognition on a group basis terminates. A subordinate then ﬁle for a separate exemption letter by following the standard in Rev. Proc.
(updated annually) and submitting the appropriate cation (e.g., Form
including paying the user fee). Note: The subordinate may also join another group, or if statutorily exempt or required to ﬁle an application, continue as exempt without recognition. to Pub
, Application Procedures for Exempt Recognition - for requirements, forms and procedures. (
) If terminating a subordinate in a group ruling, see the notiﬁcation in IRM
) For all subordinate termination cases, prepare Form
-A to update the status to

When a central organization dissolves/terminates, is revoked, or relinquishes its exemption, then recognition on a group basis terminates. A subordinate may then ﬁle for a separate exemption letter by following the standard procedures in Rev. Proc. 2020-5 (updated annually) and submitting the appropriate appli- cation (e.g., Form 1023 including paying the user fee).
Note: For other case closing procedures, please see IRM 4.75.16 Case Closing Procedures.
A central organization’s group ruling terminates when:

a. A central organization notiﬁes the IRS that it is going out of existence ﬁling a return. b. Its exemption is revoked (automatically or manually). c. It ﬁles a ﬁnal return. d. The IRS revokes the group ruling letter.

when a central organization notiﬁes them that it’s dissolving its group ruling (but not ing). (

) When possible, attempt to coordinate exams of central and subordinate zations. If you’re auditing subordinate organizations, check AIMS to see central organization and/or the group return is under audit. Contact the nation group to discuss the exam issues and coordinate actions. (
) Mandatory Review follows these actions when these events occur: For all central organization revocations:
Mandatory Review or Appeals issues the ﬁnal letter (revocation or FADL to the central organization.)
The reviewer, or Appeals, notiﬁes the manager, Mandatory Review, of the issuance of the letter to the central organization.
The manager, Mandatory Review, in turn notiﬁes the Area Manager, GL\FIU, of the revocation of the central organization.
The manager, Mandatory Review, secure emails the area managers giving directions on any subordinates in their invento- ries. See Exhibit
for all
(c) revocations. As all
(c) Organizations Are Subject to IRC

ends, either the statute coordinator, Mandatory Review, or Appeals, depending on the ﬁle’s location, notiﬁes the manager, Mandatory Review of whether a petition was ﬁled with the court.
The manager, Mandatory Review, informs the applicable area manager.
If no petition was ﬁled, the manager, Mandatory Review, secure emails the area managers to proceed with ﬁnal actions. See Exhibit
Note: Cases where a petition was ﬁled remain in suspense.

Upon notiﬁcation by Appeals or Counsel of the conclusion of the court case(s), the manager, Mandatory Review, secure emails the area managers to remove cases from suspense and conclude the exams. See Exhibit
and Exhibit
) Follow these actions for the central and subordinate organizations:
Organizations Examination Procedures

ends, either the statute coordinator, Mandatory Review, or Appeals, depending on the ﬁle’s location, notiﬁes the manager, Mandatory Review of a petition was ﬁled with the court.

Exempt Organizations Examination Procedures
This Page Intentionally Left Blank
Covered by a Group Ruling 4.75.24 page
CERTIFIED MAIL
Dear [Sir or
This is a ﬁnal adverse determination regarding your exempt status under section 501(c)[_] of the Internal Revenue Code (the Code).
[Insert applicable and appropriate summary of the reasons for the revocation.]
Contributions to your organization are no longer deductible. {Note: If, the organization has deductibility code “2”, this paragraph is not applicable}

You are required to ﬁle income tax returns on Form [1120 or 1041]. If you have not already ﬁled these returns and the agent has not provided you instructions for converting your previously ﬁled Form(s) 990 [or 990-EZ or 990-BL or 990-PF] to Form(s) 1120 [or Form(s) 1041], you should ﬁle these income tax returns with the appropriate Service Center for the tax year[s] ending [date], and for all tax years there- after in accordance with the instructions of the return.
Processing of income tax returns and assessments of any taxes due will not be delayed should a petition for declaratory judgment be ﬁled under section 7428 of the Internal Revenue Code.
4.75 Exempt Organizations Examination Procedures

If you decide to contest this determination, you may ﬁle an action for declaratory judgment under the provisions of section 7428 of the Code in one of the following three venues: United States Tax Court, the United States Court of Federal Claims, or the United States District Court for the District of Columbia. A petition or complaint in one of these three courts must be ﬁled before the 91st day after date this determination was mailed to you if you wish to seek review of our determination. Please contact the clerk of the respective court for rules and the appropriate forms regarding ﬁling petitions for declaratory judgment by referring to the enclosed Publication 892. Please note that the United States Tax Court is the only one of these courts where a declaratory judgment action can be pursued without the services of a lawyer. You may write to the courts at the following addresses:
United States Tax Court
Second Street, NW Washington, DC
US Court of Federal Claims
Madison Place, NW Washington, DC
S. District Court for the District of
Constitution Ave., N.W.

You also have the right to contact the Office of the Taxpayer Advocate. If you wish to seek review of determination, a petition or complaint must be ﬁled in one of these three courts before the 91st day after the date this determination was mailed to you. The Taxpayer Advocate cannot reverse a legally correct tax determination, or extend the time ﬁxed by law that you have to ﬁle a petition in a United States court. The Taxpayer Advocate can, however, see that a tax matter that may not have been resolved through normal channels gets prompt and proper handling. You may call toll-free, 1-877-777- 4778, and ask for Taxpayer Advocate Assistance. If you prefer, you may contact your local Taxpayer Advocate at:
If you have any questions, please contact the person whose name and telephone number are shown in the heading of this letter.
Covered by a Group Ruling 4.75.24
Date: [Insert date]
CERTIFIED MAIL
Dear [Sir or Madam]:

This is a ﬁnal adverse determination regarding your exempt status under section 501(c)[_] of the Internal Revenue Code (the Code). Our favorable determination letter to you dated [date] is hereby revoked and you are no longer exempt under section 501(a) of the Code effective [date].
revocation of your exempt status was made for the following reason[s]:
Contributions to your organization are no longer deductible. {Note: If, the organization has deductibility code “2”, this paragraph is not

Revenue Procedure 80-27 provides guidance on group exemptions. According to this revenue procedure, when we terminate your tax exemption, we also terminate your group exemption. Effective [date], your Group Exemption Number [insert GEN] is no longer valid. Please tell your subordinates of this action. Each subordinate seeking recognition of tax exemption should ﬁle an individual applica- tion or ﬁle a Form 990 series return, as appropriate.

You are required to ﬁle federal tax returns for the tax period(s) shown above. Unless an extension of time is granted or the returns are already ﬁled, send them to Ogden Service Center within 60 days the date on this letter. Returns for later years are ﬁled with the appropriate service center indicated in the return instructions.
16 4.75 Exempt Organizations Examination Procedures
4.75.24-2 (Cont. 1) (02-12-2013) Organization 90-Day Final Adverse Determination Letter (501(c))

A petition or complaint in one of these three courts must be ﬁled before the 91st day after the date this determination was mailed to you if you wish to seek review of our determination. Please contact the clerk of the respective court for rules and the appropriate forms regarding ﬁling petitions for declaratory judgment by referring to the enclosed Publication 892. Please note that the United States Tax Court is the only one of these courts where a declaratory judgment action can be pursued without the services of a lawyer. You may write to the courts at the following addresses:
United States Tax Court
Second Street, NW Washington, DC
U.S. Court of Federal Claims
Madison Place, NW Washington, DC
S. District Court for the District of
Constitution Ave., N.W. Washington, DC

Filing a petition for declaratory judgment however, does not delay the processing of income tax returns and assessments of any taxes due. A petition or complaint must be ﬁled in one of these 3 courts before the 91st day after the date this determination was mailed to you.

You have the right to contact the Taxpayer Advocate Service. Their assistance is not a substitute for established IRS procedures, such as the formal appeals process. They cannot reverse a legally correct tax determination, or extend the time ﬁxed by law that you have to ﬁle a petition in a United States court. However, they can see that a tax matter that may not have been resolved through normal channels gets prompt and proper handling. You may call toll-free 1-877-777-4778 and ask for Taxpayer Advocate assistance. If you prefer, you may contact your local Taxpayer Advocate at:
If you have any questions, please contact the person listed above.
to Proposed Action - Section 7428
Organizations Covered by a Group Ruling 4.75.24 page
E-Mail message from Manager, Mandatory Review, to Area Managers Regarding the Revocation a Central Organization (501(c)- FADL Issued)
Subject: Central Organization Revocation, Final Adverse Determination Letter Issued

On [insert date], Mandatory Review issued a 90- day adverse ﬁnal determination letter proposing revocation to [insert name of central organization]. Under Rev. Proc. 80-27, the group exemption is terminated. Any organiza- tion under GEN [insert GEN] will now be updated to EO BMF status 28 and be subject to a Form 1120 ﬁling requirement.

Please check your inventory to see if you have any subordinate organizations included in the group ruling of aforementioned parent under examination. If you have cases in status 10, please survey the case. If you have cases in status 12, continue to pursue any excise and/or employment taxes. For income tax purposes for years prior to [insert effective date of revocation], continue to pursue unrelated business income. For years after that date, follow the instructions in IRM 4.75.31 for converted returns. For any cases where you are pursuing revo- cation but no taxes, survey the case. The appropriate closing letter is a custom letter.
18 4.75 Exempt Organizations Examination
E-Mail message from Manager, Mandatory Review, to Area Managers Regarding the Revocation a Central Organization - FADL Not Petitioned)

On [insert date], Mandatory Review issued a 90-day ﬁnal adverse determination letter proposing revocation to [insert name of central organization], which did not ﬁle a petition with the courts. Under Rev. Proc. 80-27, the group exemption is terminated. Any organization under GEN [insert GEN] is to be updated to EO BMF status 28 and is subject to a Form 1120 ﬁling requirement.

Please check your inventory to see if you have any subordinate organizations included in the group ruling of the aforementioned parent under examination. If you have cases in status 10, please survey the case. If you have cases in status 12, continue to pursue any excise and/or employment taxes. For income tax purposes for years prior to [insert effective date of revocation], continue to pursue unrelated business income. For subsequent years, see IRM 4.75.31 for converted returns. If pursuing revocation but no taxes, survey the case. The appro- priate closing letter is a custom letter.
Covered by a Group Ruling 4.75.24 page

Subject: Central Organization Final Adverse Letter Petitioned

On [insert date], Mandatory Review issued a 90-day ﬁnal adverse determination letter proposing revocation to [insert name of central organization]. The organization has lost its court case. Under Rev. Proc. 80-27, the group exemption is terminated. Any organization under GEN [insert GEN] is to be updated to EO BMF status 28 and is subject to a Form 1120 ﬁling requirement.

check your inventory to see if you have any subordinate organizations included in the group ruling of parent under examination. If you have cases in status 10, please survey the case. If you have in status 12, continue to pursue any excise and/or employment taxes. For income tax purposes for to [insert effective date of revocation], continue to pursue unrelated business income. For subsequent see IRM 4.75.31 for converted returns. If pursuing revocation but no taxes, survey the case. The appro- closing letter is a custom letter.
20 4.75 Exempt Organizations Examination
Secure E-Mail message from Manager, Mandatory Review, to Area Managers Regarding the Revocation of a Central Organization (Courts Rejected)
Subject: Central Organization Final Adverse Letter Petitioned

On [insert date], Mandatory Review issued a 90-day ﬁnal adverse determination letter proposing revocation to [insert name of central organization]. We did not prevail in the court case. Therefore, please check your inventory to see if you have any subordinate cases in suspense. If so, please remove those cases from suspense and continue with the examinations.
